You're contending here that the constitution requires an arrest warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then you, as I understood it to say that if a law enforcement officer is armed with an arrest warrant such as you say in this case the constitution requires.
Then he is authorized to arrest the person wherever he's found, you said that didn't you?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: He can do that without a warrant, yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And does that give greater or lesser protection to the interest of homeowners if he's armed with a warrant to arrest an individual, can he then break into every house in the neighborhood --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Oh, no!

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- looking for that individual because it's a valid arrest wherever that --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Oh, no --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- person is in fact found whatever the suspicion maybe as to whether he's going to be there?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, absolutely not.
I'm saying that the arrest -- not at all, I'm suggesting that -- that in fact that's Lang versus Gailstiene I believe in the Fourth Circuit.
That I'm saying with a warrant to arrest, you must have probable cause to believe that he has committed a crime and a reasonable basis to believe he's in the premises where you're going and --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but you don't need to -- have it that determined by a warrant that he's in some premises.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, that's by statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well no, no, no but where -- not here to bother about New York statutes or the statutes of any other states.
We don't have any business with those except as to --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I was going to an assumption this be would be inserted into New York statute of law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- if they may involve a federal question, where -- to here as to what the -- does the federal constitution require?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: It requires an -- a determination of probable cause as --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: To arrest the person.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: To arrest the person.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Wherever found.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Wherever found, but only if he's in his home is a warrant required.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: You do not require a warrant for the public way.
If you know you're going --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But obviously when they get the -- they won't know at the time whether the man is in his home or not in his home or maybe he's out in the public street or some other public place --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- maybe it's in somebody else's home.
So what they do is get a warrant to arrest him, right, under your submission?
Does the constitution requires an arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: If they must inform the magistrate that it is to be within the home.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well that's what I didn't get.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes, that why --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How can they know --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -- six hours in advance that he will or will not be within his home?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: They can anticipate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You just told me awhile ago that it need not say in the warrant that he'd -- they can arrest in the home.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: It must say in the supporting papers that we are seeking a warrant --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought you said just awhile ago it did not require any showing in connection with getting in a warrant that there was probable cause to believe that he was in the house?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what I thought what you said too.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, then I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well you said exactly that.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Then I must clarify that Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let me test that by this hypothetical -- not hypothetical, real question.
How many warrants would you just guess roughly have been issued and are outstanding and have not yet been executed in the City of New York?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: By --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: By all the policeman in New York.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I have no idea.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thousands aren't there, thousands?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Not arrest warrants, no Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, I think -- if you're thinking about bench warrants --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When you look at the statistics and you find that at any given time in any big city there are thousands of arrest warrants outstanding and when a policeman has any doubt they have a system of checking in to see if there's an outstanding warrant on a person they've stopped for a traffic accident.
Or the policemen may have six outstanding warrants in his pocket for his particular precinct or district.
They aren't issued with the view that necessarily they're going to be executed within 48 hours.
They may have a time limit by law, but there are a great many unexecuted warrants floating around in police departments in this country.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I think those --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: State warrants, I'm talking about.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: -- those are essentially bench warrants which are issued for suspects.
In New York City the high statistics is not the unexecuted arrest warrant, it's the unexecuted bench warrant where there's been an --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Which is an arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's an arrest warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: After an accusatory instrument.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, it is an arrest warrant, isn't it?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: But with respect to -- I think if the officer intends to make an arrest within the home, he must come before the magistrate --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And so what?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: -- so stating and that he must have established on the papers that he has probable cause to believe that there is -- that the defendant has committed a crime and that he has reason to belief -- to believe that he is in his home.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So in a lot of circumstances then he'll have to come back if he wants to -- because you -- I am sure there'll be a lot of arrest warrants issued for -- to arrest the man before they know where he is or what -- where he lives or anything else if -- and if they had -- and if he's got that kind of a warrant in his pocket that doesn't authorize an arrest in a home, and you say the warrant never needs to do that.

But if he hasn't -- if there were some -- if he doesn't know that there are underlying papers that establish some reason to believe that he's in some house like his, he's got to go back to the magistrate and say, “I now believe this man's at home so I want to -- and I just want to tell that.
You don't need to change the warrant I just want to tell you that.”

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, I think he has to have -- there has to be a connection between going to the home.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, does the magistrate have to agree and decide that there's probable cause to believe that he's in the house?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then at that time?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No.
Probable cause?
In the sense of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Reasonable suspicion --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Reason for believe, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or then does he then have to make a decision and evidence that's somewhere?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Under our present system, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but what about the federal constitution?
Does it require him to make some conclusion or not?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I think yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Well, I don't know in the constitution, but I think that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's what you're arguing --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: He has to determine on the application before him, papers --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, where does he determine it, does he put it in the warrant?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: It would depend what the warrant would say.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, all I want to know is what you -- what your submission is the federal constitution requires the magistrate to find with respect to whether or not the man is in the house.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I -- my submission is that it state that in time the warrant was obtained, there were two things, probable cause for the crime and reason for belief that he is at home.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well if -- is it -- would be sufficient if he just knows where his home is?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The address of his home?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There's a John Smith and he lives at 2020 Main Street.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes, like that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And is that enough?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then you say you can arrest him in public without that warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes, they can do that under Watson.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And he can arrest him in his home only with that warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you say that the federal constitution requires, like the state law, that at the time he gets there --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- there must be federal -- reasonable cause to believe that he's in the house.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I'm sorry if I've confused you Mr. Justice, I thought that was what my adversary was saying.
I say the federal --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: -- constitution requires only probable cause to believe commission of the crime --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right, that's an arrest warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: -- in order to enter the house.
Not that it requires that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So the -- so that -- so the warrant saying really doesn't protect the house then, it protects -- it really is a protection of him personally.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: It's a protection of the house insofar as the arrest is to be made there.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's a protection of him --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I guess --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- if he's in his house.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I'll put it this way.
You submit this on your brief, your position is on here, you agree with the position you've stated in your brief?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think a warrant is in anyway infirm that it does no more than give the name of the person to be arrested without any address, without any more?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: That would depend what kind of a warrant --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: An arrest warrant, an arrest warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I would say not necessarily if --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not -- well, yes or no under the federal constitution, that's all we're talking about.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Under the federal constitution, I do not think.
I think there have to be a premises identified.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What, premises of the person to be arrested?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Hellerstein --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- extraordinary thing.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whether it says John Smith and address unknown --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you need a new --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: John Smith address unknown and his address is unknown.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: If that was --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That there's plenty of reason to --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: If this Court had held --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- there's a probable cause to believe that John Smith committed a criminal offense.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: If this Court had held that the warrant was required so far as the probable cause to believe commission of the crime, I think it would be sufficient, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: And then the officers locating the premises could go in without warrant.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Help me Mr. Hellerstein, I have never seen a warrant that said what you said, that this is a warrant for the arrest of John Doe, and if you find him in his house, you're going to arrest him there.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: There are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I have never seen one like that.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: There are John Doe warrants Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: This isn't John -- I mean this is James Smith.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: A real one.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: This is, what's his name, Theodore Payton, and if you find him at home, you can arrest him at home.
I've never seen a warrant like that.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Neither have I.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I don't know what --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought you said the warrant had to say that they can arrest him at home?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, I think -- what I meant to say is that the warrant had to be obtained in order for there to be an arrest within the home.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, it doesn't have to say so in the warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He can be arrested in a public place without a warrant.
He can be arrested in his or somebody else's home only with a warrant --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: That is my --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- an arrest warrant.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Let me be -- probably repeating but it seems to me there'd been some misunderstanding.
In this very case, talking about Mr. Payton, as I understand the sequence of events they'd learned his identity at one time and his name at another time and his address at another time.

If at the time before they knew his address, they knew his identity and a probable cause to believe he was responsible for the offense and they got an arrest warrant for that person without naming an address.
They had then taken that warrant, later learned his address and broken down the door as they did in this case.
Would you concede they acted within the Constitution?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: If they had the arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but with no address on it.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I would be reluctant to concede that Mr. Justice Stevens, because I've had no experience with that context.
I think that I might go so far as to say that mainly because the warrant had been obtained by a magistrate who had made the determination that there was new probable cause.
And once the determination was made by a magistrate --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you think there may be a constitutional difference between a warrant that includes the man's address and one that does not?
That's the delay.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where whom?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I don't think there was a difference.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, otherwise you should concede that because you have conceded, if I understand you correctly, that if the warrant includes his address that's all that's necessary.
They don't know where he is.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: They get a warrant to get to his -- to arrest this man.
They know where he lives.
They go out the first place they look is in his home and nobody answers the door so they break it down.
You say that's all right, but it's not all right if they don't know his address before they get the warrant.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is that your position?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, I think that in terms of what the constitution required a warrant --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's what we're talking about here.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: -- it should have the man's address in it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you're saying then that the -- there's a constitutional difference depending on whether they get his address in the warrant or not?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I'm not certain of that though.
I'm not certain that is -- I think the key thing is that the warrant --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It seems to me that if you take that position you are really agreeing with Mr. Justice White that you want some kind of constitutional protection on knowing whether he's in the house or not, and that would be more like a search warrant.
And then you're going to say the time you go in to get the warrant, you got to be able to predict whether he'd be in the house at the time they get there or not.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Well, that's not what I'm after.
I'm after the determination that a magistrate makes with respect to prior -- to going to the home.
I don't know what the experience would be or in the Constitution --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if your big worry is having the magistrate's confirmation as to probable cause to -- that this man committed a crime, I would think you would like to urge that just generally that there just should be arrest warrants at anytime whenever you think at anytime you get them.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Mr. Justice, I can --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And not just for the house if there'd be -- if aim of this protection as to -- is not protected -- if it isn't aimed at protecting the privacy of the home but just probable cause to commit with respect to the commission of the crime.
That's general applicability.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: After the Court's decision in Watson, I can urge that.
What I'm saying --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you might be back though another day, do you?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I think it'd be a while but I believe that Watson says is not required.
What I'm trying simply to say is that a warrant to enter the home is required beyond Watson.
That is -- I'm not seeking a warrant for arrest.
I'm seeking for a warrant for arrest within the home.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let me see if I understand the net of your argument.
Is it this that whenever there is an arrest, it can be made without a warrant only if they're arrested in a public place?
If they are arrested anywhere else, they must have a warrant?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, Mr. Chief Justice.
I think that states it far too --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, the pieces of your argument add up to that for me.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: No, I'm simply saying that there can be an arrest -- there can be no arrest within the home without a warrant.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How about his office?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: An office?
Depending on the nature of the office and the extent --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, where does the constitution help you there, that's what we're guided by.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Just in the continuum of this Court's -- that's not this case.
This Court has another decisions, afforded offices some protection under the Fourth Amendment depending on what the expectations of privacy were, who had access to the office.
I would be willing to concede that an office that was open to the public to do business was not in any way like the home.
And if that's not --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The lawyer's office, the private office.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I think the interior of my office where I might work alone would have the same privacy of the home, but not necessarily where I see clients and do business.
That would be I would draw the line.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Some of the members of the Court would like to have an opportunity to examine those copies of bench warrants or grand jury warrants if your friend has no objection, would you leave them?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I'd be most happy to leave them Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If you'll deposit them with the clerk.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I will do that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
